history.title: Department of Computer Education
history.summary: The Department of Computer Education was established in 1991. Currently, it has more than 10 qualified faculty members who are experts in various fields and recognized at the national level. The department offers programs ranging from graduate studies in Computer Technology, Master's degrees in Computer Technology (Computer Education and Multimedia Technology branches), to Doctoral degrees in Computer Education. Research areas include AI-based CAI, Multimedia, Computer Graphics, Image Processing, Educational Information Systems, Network Systems, Software Engineering, and Edutainment. The department is well-equipped with academic knowledge and research capabilities, producing high-quality graduates. It collaborates with national and international organizations as well as the business sector. Currently, there are over 2,000 alumni who are key forces in various organizations in Thailand's computer and information systems industry.
history.description: From small beginnings, the Department of Computer Education has expanded to become a center of educational technology knowledge, working with school networks and the private sector nationwide. The timeline below shows the department's significant developments.

event0.title: The Beginning
event0.description: Between 1984 - 1987, a group of Electrical Science faculty members, including Ajarn Prasert Rungrote, Ajarn Pichetpong Vorasangapong, Ajarn Prapas Apipatchaniyakul, and Ajarn Pornjit Songtham, jointly laid the foundation for technology and computer instruction for student teachers to support the increasing demand from schools and the industrial sector.

event1.title: First Computer Laboratory
event1.description: Established Computer Laboratory Room 205 as the first computer lab for the TCT program. It used basic application programs running on 24 TWC machines (IBMPC CPU Intel 80386SX-16MHz) with 256 KB memory and 5.25-inch disk drives. This was a significant milestone that gave student teachers the opportunity to seriously experience contemporary technology.

event2.title: Afternoon TCT Program & Lab Establishment
event2.description: The demand for the TCT program increased. The Ministry of University Affairs considered the computer field as a shortage area. The Dean supported opening an afternoon program (3-year curriculum) for the first time, admitting 20 students in the first batch.

event3.title: First TCT Graduates
event3.description: The first batch of graduates in Industrial Education (Computer Technology) completed their studies on time and received their degrees on October 18, 1993. This paved the way for the TCT name, which was well-received by the labor market, with all graduates finding employment.

event4.title: First Curriculum Improvement
event4.description: This year saw the first curriculum update to be more modern, including a proposal to separate from the Department of Electrical Education to establish the Department of Computer Education (first name proposed) for better administration and budget management.

event5.title: Establishment of the Department
event5.description: The project to establish the department was drafted and proposed through the institute's committees, ending at the Ministry of University Affairs. The Dean, Ajarn Samer Rernganant, and I had to clarify with the Ministry's committee several times.

event6.title: 2 Years of Hardware Development
event6.description: The policy to mobilize budget for specific departments by the Faculty of Technical Education executives made 1996 a year of development for the Department of Computer Education. Combined with the project to accelerate the production of graduates in shortage areas, the department received a budget of nearly 8 million baht in 1996.

event7.title: 3 Years of Personnel Development
event7.description: After the department was established, it was allocated personnel positions from both the normal budget and the accelerated graduate production project. It also received scholarships for faculty to study abroad. This was a good opportunity for many lecturers to study abroad before the economic crisis cut the project short.

event8.title: Entering Information Systems
event8.description: With budget support from the Faculty, the department designed and installed the Faculty's computer network, named TechEd Net, in Room 207. This allowed full use of Intranet/Internet for information tasks. The department also joined the project to accept outstanding students from technical colleges nationwide into the TCT program without entrance exams.

event9.title: First MTCT Students
event9.description: In the 1999 academic year, the department admitted the first batch of Master's students (MTCT) in Multimedia Technology and Computer Education. There were 21 students, some alumni and some from outside. The undergraduate TCT program continued to admit the same number of students, bringing the total to about 350.

event10.title: 10th Anniversary
event10.description: In early 2000, Computer Laboratory 511 was established for graduate students. It was considered the best computer lab in the faculty, equipped with complete audiovisual systems, costing nearly 2 million baht. About 130 TCT graduates completed their studies on time this year.

event11.title: Entering the 2nd Decade
event11.description: The Department of Computer Education entered its second decade firmly with quality personnel and long teaching experience. The department focused on continuous curriculum and research development to align with IT changes and digital labor market demands.

event12.title: First CED Students
event12.description: The department admitted the first batch of Bachelor's students in Computer Education (CED) to produce graduates capable of applying IT in education and teaching. The first batch had 50 students, responding to the increasing demand in the educational technology labor market.

philosophy.title: Philosophy & Mission
philosophy.body: We believe people and technology must grow together. Our curriculum balances pedagogy, communication, and technological fluency with a strong sense of social responsibility.

vision.title: Vision
vision.body: To produce graduates who elevate communities and to build a knowledge organization that keeps Thailand at the forefront of science and technology.

mission.title: Mission
mission.body: To educate undergraduates and graduates with strong values, conduct research and outreach that can be applied in real contexts, and preserve the nation’s art and culture.

items.item1: Produce computer-technology graduates who can teach and innovate across theory and practice.
items.item2: Develop graduate specialists across multimedia, computer education, and e-commerce technology.
items.item3: Support teachers, trainers, and scholars with advanced academic development and a national knowledge network.
items.item4: Promote research and development that translates computer technology into tangible societal benefit.
